content: The Act titled "Investment Competitiveness Act of 1999" is referenced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It addresses the treatment of certain dividends of regulated investment companies. The Investment Competitiveness Act of 1999 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amends the tax treatment for certain dividends of regulated investment companies, providing an exemption for interest-related dividends received from such companies by nonresident alien individuals. Short-term capital gain dividends from regulated investment companies are generally not taxed, except for nonresident alien individuals subject to tax under subsection (a)(2). These dividends are designated as short-term capital gain dividends in written notices. The company designates short-term capital gain dividends in written notices to shareholders within 60 days after the close of its taxable year. If the total designated amount exceeds the company's qualified short-term gain for the year, the distribution of short-term capital gain dividends is based on the proportion of qualified short-term gain to the total designated amount. The term 'qualified short-term gain' for a regulated investment company is the excess of its net short-term capital gain over any net long-term capital loss for the taxable year. This calculation includes treating short-term capital gain dividends as short-term gains. The excess of net short-term capital gain over net long-term capital loss for a taxable year is determined without considering any losses from transactions after October 31. These losses are treated as arising in the next taxable year and may also apply for computing taxable income of a regulated investment company. The estate tax treatment of interest in certain regulated investment companies is amended by adding a new subsection regarding stock in a regulated investment company. The new subsection addresses the estate tax treatment of stock in a regulated investment company owned by a nonresident not a citizen of the United States. It specifies that such stock is not considered property within the United States based on the proportion of qualifying assets held by the investment company. Qualifying assets are those that would have been owned directly by the decedent. This is based on the proportion of qualifying assets held by the investment company, which are assets that would have been owned directly by the decedent. The amendment excludes interest in a domestically-controlled qualified investment entity from foreign ownership percentage calculations. Qualified investment entity includes real estate investment trusts and regulated investment companies. The amendments made by this section apply to dividends of regulated investment companies starting after the enactment date, with estate tax treatment for decedents dying after that date.
